newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - ends off as much as a point.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - ends off as much as a point.

text.p: U.S. municipal bond prices ended the week with full point losses in spots on Friday, after the figure for July durable goods was a little too good.
The U.S. Commerce Department reported that orders for big ticket items in July rose 1.6 percent, much higher than the forecast for a 0.3 percent increase.
Prices opened 1/4 to 3/8 softer on the news, then extended those losses throughout the day. By the end of the day, the market was down 3/4 overall and a point on certain names, one trader said.
Trading at the new levels was not very active, however, and was especially light in the afternoon.
In the secondary, bids on Cook County, Ill., FGIC 5-7/8s of 2022 were off 1/2 point at 99-1/4. Yields jumped six basis points, to 5.83 percent, on Lakeland, Fla., electric 5-1/2s of 2026.
The Treasury long bond was hit by durable goods as well, with the long bond heading into the New York close off 1-4/32 at 97-23/32 to yield 6.93 percent.

Municipal futures followed the same downward trend, with the September contract ending off 1-1/32 to 114-15/32. The September T-bond contract lost the same amount, leaving the MOB spread unchanged at 158 ticks.

Next week's new issue action will again be light, with the week's competitive calendar totaling $291 million and the largest single offering only $25 million. Bergen County, N.J., takes credit for that deal, set for 1100 EDT Monday.

The largest negotiated issue next week is expected to be the New York State Dormitory Authority's $377 million issue through Smith Barney Inc. The total negotiated calendar is approximately $1.7 billion for the week, with another $769 million on the day-to-day list.
Next week's data releases include Monday's existing home sales for July, Tuesday's consumer confidence report from the Conference Board, and new home sales for July on Thursday.
